newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 30.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - Jan 30.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Thursday:
-- Mercury Finance says its No. 2 official, Controller John Doyle, has disappeared and says it has uncovered accounting irregularities that force it to slash its profits for the last four years.
-- Bayer AG's U.S. subsidiary has agreed to plead guilty and pay a $50 million fine for participating in a price-fixing conspiracy over citric acid.
-- America Online agrees to return millions of dollars in credits and refunds to users frustrated by its service, giving the company's stock a boost despite the potential cost of the agreement.
-- Ford Motor reports higher fourth-quarter and full-year earnings.
-- Philip Morris reports strong earnings driven by international tobacco profits and the better-than-expected domestic performance of its Marlboro brand.
-- Late buying sends the Dow industrials up 84.66 points to 6,740.74, halting a weeklong decline.
-- Durable goods orders fell 1.7 percent in December, steeper than economists had expected.
-- The dollar rose again against the yen, but rather than cheering, some Japanese industry officials worry that a weaker yen hurts the Tokyo stock index more than it helps Japanese exports.
-- CompUSA said profits rose 27 percent in the fiscal second quarter, matching revised earnings expectations.
-- Hilton Hotels said it will file its tender offer for ITT Corp but ITT reiterates that it will probably take up to 10 business days to consider the bid.
-- Biotechnology company Chiron said it will seek a new chief executive to succeed Edward Penhoet, who will become vice chairman.
-- While the North American Free Trade Agreement has bolstered trade between the U.S., Canada and Mexico, it has made it harder for the tiny countries of the Caribbean to compete.
-- The "Star Wars" trilogy returns to screens and stores, promising big profits for News Corp's Twentieth Century Fox, its distributor, and retailers such as Hasbro, Lewis Galoob Toys and PepsiCo.
-- Spinoffs are the corporate trend du jour, with Pepsico, Westinghouse, Monsanto and General Instrument among the companies that have spinoffs under way.
-- Henry Kravis, a founding partner in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is chairman of the New York City Investment Fund, a group seeking to create jobs in New York's poor neighborhoods.
-- The Federal Aviation Administration said it would begin providing airline safety information on the World Wide Web but won't rank individual carriers.
